Amoebic dysentery: Symptoms, causes, diagnosis, treatment and prevention

Amoebic dysentery is a common intestinal infection that occurs due to unsanitary conditions, creating favorable conditions for parasites to invade and cause harm. This condition needs to be treated promptly and properly to avoid serious complications.

What is Amoebic Dysentery?
Amoebic dysentery is an intestinal infection caused by the invasion of the parasite Entamoeba histolytica. The disease can lead to diarrhea, nausea, fever and acute abdominal pain, and in many cases there are unclear symptoms.
Anyone can get amoebic dysentery. The most common areas where this occurs are tropical areas with unsanitary conditions, such as:
The restroom is not clean; Hand washing areas and utensils are not hygienic; Improper wastewater treatment
Amoebic dysentery is an intestinal infection that occurs due to unsanitary conditions

Amoeba life cycle
The group of protists always forms surrounding cysts to cope with harsh environmental conditions. In other words, this is an important part of their life cycle.(2)
The main cause of amoebic dysentery is the parasite Entamoeba histolytica. This type of protozoa forms cysts and passes out into the environment in feces. When food or water containing Entamoeba histolytica cysts enters the digestive tract, the amoeba is immediately released and the infection begins. During the active phase, Entamoeba histolytica exists only in the host and fresh feces. On the contrary, cysts are always present in water, soil, and food, especially in humid conditions.
With a tough outer protective layer, this bacterial cyst can survive continuously for weeks, withstanding heat levels of up to 68 degrees Celsius for 5 minutes. In addition, Entamoeba histolytica is also resistant to certain chemicals. That is why amoebic dysentery is relatively difficult to control. Bacteria that attack the intestinal wall have the risk of causing serious damage. In many cases, it also enters the bloodstream, causing damage to the liver, lungs, brain and spleen.
Anatomy of the bacterium Entamoeba histolytica

Cause of amoebic dysentery
The cause of amoebic dysentery is the invasion of the parasite Entamoeba histolytica into the digestive system. Infection routes that must be mentioned include: (1)
Eating food and drinking drinks contaminated with parasites; Touch the surface containing parasite eggs and then put it in your mouth; Contact with feces, most likely to occur when: having anal sex, living or traveling to places with unsanitary conditions...

Symptoms of amoebic dysentery
Amoebic dysentery often does not manifest into specific symptoms, especially at the first infection. Patients may notice some of the following typical signs within 4 weeks of infection:
Stomach-ache; Diarrhea; Rectal bleeding; Fever; Loose stools; Nausea
Entamoeba histolytica can exist in the intestine for a long time, even without showing obvious symptoms. Therefore, immediately after living or moving to an area with unsanitary conditions, the best solution is to get examined and tested for timely detection.
Time to onset varies widely between cases, and asymptomatic infection lasts on average more than a year. The study hypothesized that this change in intensity could be due to the amoeba strain, the host's immune response, or the bacteria or viruses involved.
Diarrhea is one of the common symptoms of amoebic dysentery

Who is at risk of amoebic dysentery?
Anyone can get amoebic dysentery, however, the following people are often at higher risk: (3)
People who have traveled to tropical areas with unsanitary conditions; Immigrants and tourists from tropical regions have unsanitary conditions; People living in areas with poor sanitation; Men who have sex with men; Anal sex

Diagnosis method of amoebic dysentery
When suspecting a patient has amoebic dysentery, the doctor will initially ask about recent travel history and health status. After that, a number of tests may be ordered to make an accurate diagnosis, including:
Stool test: Patients need to provide stool samples within a few days to screen for parasites; Stool test: Patients need to provide a stool sample within a few days to screen for parasites.
Blood tests: Blood tests help determine whether the infection has spread beyond the intestines and other organs. Once the parasite spreads out of the intestine, there is a high risk that it will no longer appear in the stool.; Blood tests: Blood tests help determine whether the infection has spread beyond the intestines and other organs. Once the parasites spread from the intestines, there is a high risk that they will no longer appear in the stool.
Diagnostic imaging tests (ultrasound, CT scan): The main purpose is to check for lesions on the liver or spread to other organs in the abdomen and the whole body.; Diagnostic imaging tests (ultrasound, CT scan): The main purpose is to check for lesions on the liver or spread to other organs in the abdomen and the whole body.
Colonoscopy: Colonoscopy is performed to check for parasitic lesions on the colon.; Colonoscopy: Colonoscopy is performed to check for parasitic damage on the colon.

Complications of amoebic dysentery
Amoebic dysentery, if not treated promptly, can lead to many complications including: (4)
Liver abscess: Parasites and pus form in the liver; Spread of parasites through the blood to the liver, lungs, brain, and other organs; Colitis, toxic megacolon; Rectovaginal fistula; Brain abscess formation; Intestinal perforation; Gastrointestinal bleeding; Peritonitis

How to treat amoebic dysentery
Antibiotics are used to treat amoebic dysentery, and there are also medications to treat gastrointestinal symptoms. Patients need to see a doctor for appropriate treatment to avoid dangerous complications.
Medication is the initial treatment solution for amoebiasis

How to prevent amoebic dysentery?
1. Maintain personal hygiene
Practice good hand hygiene before handling, preparing food, eating, and after using the toilet or handling feces; Practice good hand hygiene before handling or preparing food, eating and drinking, and after using the toilet or handling feces.
Wash your hands with soap and water, rub for at least 20 seconds, then rinse with clean water, dry with disposable paper towels or a specialized dryer; Wash your hands with soap and water, rub for at least 20 seconds, then rinse with clean water and dry with disposable paper towels or a specialized dryer.
Clean your hands regularly with 70 - 80 degree alcohol; Clean your hands regularly with 70 - 80 degree alcohol
Stop all activities of going to school, going to work and going to see a gastroenterology specialist as soon as unusual symptoms appear in the digestive tract, typically diarrhea; Stop all activities like going to school, going to work, and going to see a gastroenterology specialist as soon as unusual symptoms appear in the digestive tract, typically diarrhea.
2. Maintain food hygiene
Apply the correct food handling formula: Choose clean ingredients, always keep hands and processing utensils clean, separate raw and cooked foods, cook thoroughly before eating, store food at a safe temperature .; Apply the correct food handling formula: Choose clean ingredients, always keep hands and processing utensils clean, separate raw and cooked foods, cook thoroughly before eating, store food at a safe temperature .
Only drink boiled water or bottled water of guaranteed origin; Only drink boiled water or bottled water of guaranteed origin
Avoid drinking iced drinks of unknown origin; Avoid drinking iced drinks of unknown origin
Isolate infected or asymptomatic carriers from food processing, child care, the elderly, and immunocompromised people.; Isolate infected or asymptomatic carriers from food processing, child care, the elderly, and immunocompromised people.
Handle food properly to effectively prevent amoebic dysentery

Frequently asked questions about amoebic dysentery
Below are some useful answers related to amoebiasis that patients need to understand:
1. Is amoebic dysentery dangerous?
Amoebic dysentery can be completely cured if treated properly. In the opposite case, this condition can lead to many dangerous complications, even death. Therefore, patients need to immediately contact a medical facility in case of doubt.
2. Is amoebiasis contagious?
The Entamoeba histolytica parasite lives only in humans and is transmitted through fecal bacteria. The specific route of infection is as follows:
Touching infected feces and continued contact with the mouth; Eating food or water contaminated with parasites; Oral-anal sex
3. Can I go to school or work normally if I have amoebic dysentery?
All school and work activities should be stopped immediately when detecting amoebiasis. Along with that, patients should wash their hands thoroughly after using the toilet, bathroom or handling diapers and waste. It is important to discuss with your doctor about your health condition and when you can return to school or work after taking antibiotics.
4. What should you not eat with amoebic dysentery?
People with amoebic dysentery should avoid drinking milk and dairy products of unknown origin, raw vegetables, cold or carbonated drinks. This needs to be maintained for a few days until your doctor gives clearance.
Avoid eating sweets when you have amoebic dysentery
